title: 114_s2564
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Dine College Act of 2016". The Navajo Nation established Dine College to provide education opportunities for the Navajo people and others, focusing on economic and social development. The purpose of this Act is to ensure self-determination for the Navajo Nation and people, maintain Navajo institutions of higher education, and improve economic and social conditions through education and training. The Act defines "appropriate committees of Congress" as specific Senate and House committees, "College" as Dine College, and "infrastructure" as buildings, water/sewer facilities, roads, IT/telecom infrastructure, and classrooms of the College. The term "operation and maintenance" refers to the daily costs of running the College, while "renovation and repair" involves modernizing the infrastructure. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. SEC. 5. SURVEY, STUDY, AND REPORT. The Secretary must conduct a survey and study of all capital projects and facility needs of the College by January 31, 2017. The College must submit an inventory of necessary renovations and repairs by August 1, 2016. The report will include recommendations by the Secretary and input from the College or Navajo Nation. The Secretary will identify necessary renovations and repairs to meet health and safety standards and other requirements determined by the College. The inventory will be used as baseline data for a survey, study, and report. Administrative expenses may be covered by general appropriations. SEC. 6. GRANTS AUTHORIZED. The Secretary will provide construction grants to the College for activities such as building renovation, water and sewer facilities, and information technology infrastructure. Authorization of $2,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2017 to 2020 is allocated for these grants. Additionally, operation and maintenance grants will be given for various activities. The College will receive operation and maintenance grants for various activities, including education costs, capital expenditures, summer programs, major improvements, mandatory payments, and student services. The College will receive funding for student housing, food service, access to books, higher education programs, career and technical education, preservation of Navajo language and culture, employment opportunities, economic development, and a safe learning environment. Authorization of appropriations is also provided. Authorization of appropriations is provided for the Secretary to carry out necessary funding for fiscal years 2017 through 2020. SEC. 7. STATUS OF FUNDS.

Amounts available to the College can be treated as non-Federal, private funds for specific purposes under Federal law.

SEC. 8. EFFECT ON OTHER LAWS.

This Act supersedes the Navajo Community College Act, the Navajo Community College Assistance Act of 1978, and the Navajo Nation Higher Education Act of 2008.

SEC. 9. CONTINUING ELIGIBILITY FOR OTHER FEDERAL FUNDS. SEC. 9. CONTINUING ELIGIBILITY FOR OTHER FEDERAL FUNDS.

The College remains eligible to receive Federal funding under various authorized programs for higher education institutions.
